questions.text: Which of the following microbial life is seen in the intestines of adult humans?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Humans are born with sterile guts and acquire their commensal microbiota from the mother during egress through the birth canal and subsequently from environmental sources. A stable configuration of up to 1000 species of bacteria that achieves a biomass of ~10^12 (10 to the power of 12) colony-forming units per gram of feces is completed by three years of age , which likely persists into adult life, with each human possessing a unique combination of species.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, & C. In addition, the intestines contain other microbial life forms, including Archae, viruses, and protists

Extraedge:

The establishment and maintenance of the intestinal microbiota composition and function are controlled by the host (e.g., immune and epithelial responses), environmental (e.g. diet and antibiotics), and likely genetic . The endogenous commensal microbiota within the intestines plays a central role in the pathogenesis of IBD .

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the colon specimen shown below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ulcerative colitis Ulcerative colitis: Diffuse (nonsegmental) mucosal disease with broad areas of ulceration. The bowel wall is not thickened, and there is no cobblestoning. Ulcerative Colitis is a mucosal disease that usually involves the rectum and extends proximally to apply all or part of the colon. About 40–50% of patients have disease limited to the rectum and rectosigmoid. The mucosa is hemorrhagic, edematous, and ulcerated in more severe diseases, as in the image.

Extraedge:

With mild inflammation, the mucosa is erythematous and has a fine granular surface that resembles sandpaper. In long-standing diseases, inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) may be present due to epithelial regeneration.

questions.text: The histology of the intestine biopsy is shown below. The findings are typical of the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ulcerative colitis Medium-power view of colonic mucosa in ulcerative colitis showing diffuse mixed inflammation, basal lymphoplasmacytic, crypt atrophy and irregularity, and superficial erosion . These features are typical of chronic active ulcerative colitis. The process is limited to the mucosa and superficial submucosa, with deeper layers unaffected except in fulminant disease.

Highyeild:

In UC, two major histologic features suggest chronicity. First, the crypt architecture of the colon is distorted ; crypts may be bifid and reduced in number, often with a gap between the crypt bases and the muscularis mucosae. Second, some patients have basal plasma cells and multiple basal lymphoid aggregates. Mucosal vascular congestion, edema, and focal hemorrhage, and an inflammatory cell infiltrate of neutrophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages may be present. The neutrophils invade the epithelium, usually in the crypts.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, C, & D. Not typical suggestive features.

questions.text: What do the macroscopic findings in the colon below suggest?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Crohn's disease Crohn’s colon disease shows thickening of the wall, with stenosis, linear serpiginous ulcers, and cobblestoning of the mucosa. Crohn’s disease (CD) can affect any part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to the anus. The CD is often segmental with skip areas throughout the diseased intestine. The CD is a transmura l process.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C, & D. Not typical suggestive features.

Extraedge:

In mild disease, aphthous or small superficial ulcerations are found In more active diseases, stellate ulcerations fuse longitudinally and transversely to demarcate mucosa islands that are frequently histologically normal. This “cobblestone” appearance is characteristic of CD, both endoscopically and by barium radiography . The active CD is characterized by focal inflammation and formation of fistula tracts, which resolve by fibrosis and structuring of the bowel

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Crohn's Disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Granulomas All of the options mentioned above are seen in Crohn’s disease. The earliest lesions are aphthous ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses with loose aggregations of macrophages, which form noncaseating granulomas in all bowel wall layers. But granulomas are a characteristic feature of CD. Ulcerations and crypt abscesses are also seen in ulcerative colitis.

Extraedge:

In mild disease, aphthous or small superficial ulcerations are found In more active diseases, stellate ulcerations fuse longitudinally and transversely to demarcate mucosa islands that are frequently histologically normal. Cobblestone appearance and Granuloma are characteristic of CD.

questions.text: A patient with a complaint of 8-10 bowel movements with blood in stool is being evaluated for the severity of ulcerative colitis. On examination, the temperature is 100 F, and the pulse rate is 110 bpm. Investigation shows Hb of 8gm/dL and ESR of 40 mm/hr. What is the severity?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Severe The symptoms and signs mentioned in the question are all given in the table below under the category of “Severe.” MILD MODERATE SEVERE Bowel movements <4 per day 4-6 per day >6 per day Blood in stool Small Moderate Severe Fever None <37.5°C mean (<99.5°F) >37.5°C mean (>99.5°F) Tachycardia None <90 mean pulse >90 mean pulse Anemia Mild >75% of a normal hemoglobin $75% of a normal hemoglobin Sedimentation rate <30 mm >30 mm Endoscopic appearance Erythema, decreased vascular pattern, fine granularity Marked erythema, coarse granularity, absent vascular markings, contact bleeding, no ulcerations Spontaneous bleeding, ulcerations

questions.text: Colonoscopy in ulcerative colitis shows spontaneous bleeding and ulcerations. What is the severity of the disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Severe Fig: Colonoscopy with acute ulcerative colitis: severe colon inflammation with erythema, friability, and exudates. Endoscopically severe disease is characterized by spontaneous bleeding and ulcerations. Histologic features change more slowly than clinical features but can also be used to grade disease activity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, & C. Endoscopically mild disease is characterized by erythema, decreased vascular pattern, and mild friability. The moderate illness is characterized by marked erythema, absent vascular pattern, friability, and erosions.

Extraedge:

Patients pass a liquid stool containing blood, pus, and fecal matter when the disease is severe. Diarrhea is often nocturnal and postprandial. Severe cramping and abdominal pain can occur with severe attacks of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following describes Toxic megacolon in patients with severe attacks of UC?

options.label: A
options.text: Transverse or right colon with a diameter of < 6 cm, with increased haustration

options.label: B
options.text: Transverse or right colon with a diameter of >6 cm, with increased haustration

options.label: C
options.text: Transverse or right colon with a diameter of < 6 cm, with loss of haustration

options.label: D
options.text: Transverse or right colon with a diameter of >6 cm, with loss of haustration

questions.correct_answer: D. Transverse or right colon with a diameter of >6 cm, with loss of haustration
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Transverse or right colon with a diameter of >6 cm, with loss of haustration Toxic megacolon is defined as a transverse or right colon with a diameter of >6 cm , with loss of haustration in patients with severe attacks of UC. It occurs rarely and can be triggered by electrolyte abnormalities and narcotics. Patients with toxic colitis have severe pain and bleeding, and those with megacolon have hepatic tympany. Both may have signs of peritonitis if a perforation has occurred.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B. Loss of haustration. Option: C. Diameter >6cm.

Extraedge:

About 50% of acute dilations will resolve with conservative management alone, but urgent colectomy is required for those who do not improve. Perforation is the most dangerous of the local complications, and the physical signs of peritonitis may not be obvious, mainly if the patient receives glucocorticoids.

questions.text: During colonoscopy in a patient with UC, a stricture is found that blocks the passage of the colonoscope. What is NOT true about it?

options.label: A
options.text: It should be presumed benign until proven otherwise

options.label: B
options.text: It is an indication of surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. It should be presumed benign until proven otherwise
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It should be presumed benign until proven otherwise Strictures occur in 5–10% of patients and are always a concern in UC because of the possibility of underlying neoplasia . Although benign strictures can form from UC's inflammation and fibrosis, criticisms impassable with the colonoscopy should be presumed malignant until proven otherwise . A stricture that prevents the passage of the colonoscope indicates surgery .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. A stricture that prevents the passage of the colonoscope is an indication for surgery. Option: C. Strictures occur in 5–10% of patients and are always a concern in UC because of the possibility of underlying neoplasia.

Extraedge:

UC patients occasionally develop anal fissures, perianal abscesses, or hemorrhoids, but extensive perianal lesions should suggest CD.

questions.text: All of the following clinical features suggest Crohn's disease EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High spiking fever Although CD usually presents as acute or chronic bowel inflammation, the site of disease influences the clinical manifestations. The most common site of inflammation is the terminal ileum -ileocolitis -There is history recurrent episodes of right lower quadrant pain and diarrhea. A low-grade fever is usually noted. High-spiking fever suggests intra-abdominal abscess formation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, D. Because the most common site of inflammation is the terminal ileum, the usual presentation of ileocolitis is a chronic history of recurrent episodes of right lower quadrant pain and diarrhea. Option B: Weight loss is common—typically 10–20% of body weight—and develops due to diarrhea, anorexia, and fear of eating.

Extraedge:

Sometimes the initial presentation mimics acute appendicitis with pronounced right lower quadrant pain, a palpable mass, fever, and leukocytosis. Pain is usually colicky; it precedes and is relieved by defecation. questions.text: Diarrhea is characteristic of active disease in Jejunoileitis. What is the cause of diarrhea?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacterial overgrowth in obstructive stasis or fistulization

options.label: B
options.text: Bile acid malabsorption due to a diseased or resected terminal ileum

options.label: C
options.text: Intestinal inflammation with decreased water absorption and increased secretion of electrolytes

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Jejunoileitis is an extensive inflammatory disease associated with a loss of digestive and absorptive surface, resulting in malabsorption and steatorrhea. Diarrhea is characteristic of active disease. Its causes include Bacterial overgrowth in obstructive stasis or fistulization, Bile acid malabsorption due to a diseased or resected terminal ileum, Intestinal inflammation with decreased water absorption and increased secretion of electrolytes and Enteroenteric fistula(e).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, & C. All can cause diarrhea.

Extraedge:

Many patients need intravenous iron since oral iron is poorly tolerated and often ineffective . A combination of vitamin D deficiency, hypocalcemia, and prolonged glucocorticoid use causes vertebral fractures. Hence most patients should take daily multivitamins, calcium, and vitamin D supplements

questions.text: A patient comes to OPD with fresh blood or blood-stained mucus, constipation, fever, and anorexia. And weight loss. On per rectum, colon involvement is noticed. On endoscopy of the colon, a fine granular surface is seen with pseudo polyps. The following is not an extraintestinal manifestation of the disease:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior uveitis The pathology is ulcerative colitis with the rectum and sigmoid colon involvement showing fresh blood. Patients with proctitis usually pass fresh blood or blood-stained mucus , either mixed with stool or streaked onto the surface of a standard or complex With proctitis or proctosigmoiditis, proximal transit slows , which may account for the constipation commonly seen in patients with the distal disease. On colonoscopy, with mild inflammation, the mucosa is erythematous and has a fine granular surface that resembles sandpaper.

Highyeild:

Common Extra intestinal manifestations of Ulcerative Colitis: Dermatological: Erythema nodosum (EN), Pyoderma gangrenosum, Ocular: conjunctivitis, anterior uveitis/iritis, and episcleritis. Rheumatological : Peripheral arthritis, Ankylosing spondylitis. Hepatobiliary : Hepatomegaly with hepatic steatosis, Primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Extraedge:

Erythema nodosum, peripheral arthritis, and episcleritis correlate with bowel disease activity. Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) usually presents after the diagnosis of IBD, but it may occur years before the onset of bowel symptoms, run a course independent of the bowel disease, 5% of patients with UC have Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), but 50–75% of patients with PSC have IBD. Although it can be recognized after the diagnosis of IBD, PSC can be detected earlier or even years after proctocolectomy.

questions.text: A patient with a chronic history of diarrhea and blood in stool and presents with multiple fistulae in the perineum and multiple strictures in the small intestine. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Crohn's disease Typical findings suggest a diagnosis of Crohn's disease—associations - abdominal pain, severe diarrhea, fatigue, weight loss, and malnutrition. Structuring can occur in the colon in 4–16% o f patients and produce symptoms of bowel obstruction. The perianal disease affects about one-third of patients with Crohn’s colitis and is manifested by incontinence, large hemorrhoidal tags, anal strictures, anorectal fistulas, and perirectal abscesses.

Extraedge:

If the endoscope cannot traverse a stricture in Crohn’s colitis, surgical resection should be considered, especially if the patient has symptoms of chronic obstruction. Ileal or colonic strictures may be dilated with balloons introduced through the colonoscope. Strictures ≤4 cm in length and those at anastomotic sites respond better to endoscopic dilation. Not all patients with perianal fistula will have endoscopic evidence of colonic inflammation. A diverting colostomy may help heal severe perianal disease or rectovaginal fistulas, but the disease almost always recurs with re-anastomosis. These patients often require a total proctocolectomy and ileostomy.

Toxic megacolon is defined as a transverse or right colon with a diameter of >6 cm , with loss of haustration, and is seen in patients with severe attacks of UC. It occurs rarely and can be triggered by electrolyte abnormalities and Patients with toxic colitis have severe pain and bleeding, and those with megacolon have hepatic tympany.
